importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Publication year of Baek Se-hee's first memoir, which became a bestseller in South Korea and sparked widespread conversations about mental health.
Year when the English translation of Baek Se-hee's memoir was released, leading to international acclaim and inclusion in global bestseller lists.
Date of Baek Se-hee's death announcement and the release of the organ donation agency's statement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2018 to 2025 represents the rise and global impact of Baek Se-hee’s work, particularly in mental health discourse and public awareness.

keyTakeAways: Baek Se-hee, a South Korean author, died at age 35 after writing the bestselling memoir 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki,' which opened honest conversations about depression and mental health.
Her book, blending memoir and self-help, resonated deeply in South Korea and gained international popularity after being translated into English in 2022.
The memoir addressed her experiences with dysthymia, a chronic form of depression, and her ongoing struggle with emotional well-being despite life changes.
Baek Se-hee donated her organs—heart, lungs, liver, and both kidneys—saving the lives of five people, demonstrating a commitment to altruism and public service.
Her younger sister Baek Da-hee and translator Anton Hur paid heartfelt tributes, highlighting Baek’s compassionate nature and lasting influence on readers globally.

summaryOfNewsArticle: South Korean author Baek Se-hee, known for her deeply personal and emotionally raw memoirs, died at age 35. Her first memoir, 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki,' became a bestseller in South Korea upon publication in 2018, and after being translated into English in 2022, it gained international acclaim, reaching the Sunday Times Bestsellers List and receiving a New York Times recommendation. The book explores her struggles with dysthymia and depression, portraying the tension between a desire to end life and the pleasure derived from simple joys like tteokbokki. Baek wrote a second memoir in 2019 detailing her continued battle with chronic depression. She donated her heart, lungs, liver, and both kidneys, saving five lives. Her sister Baek Da-hee and translator Anton Hur honored her memory, highlighting her compassionate nature and profound impact on readers worldwide.
title: Baek Se-hee, author of bestselling memoir ‘I Want To Die But I Want To Eat Tteokbokki,’ dead at 35
